text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with christmas hamlet that's right
to eat or not to eat is not going to be
a question because these home cured
individually sized little mini hams were
amazing
less fatty less salty all-natural and of
course super cool-looking
so let me show you how to do these so
we're going to start with a fairly
standard brine these need to cure for
two days before we cook them so we're
going to take some kosher salt some
brown sugar some allspice some ground
cloves and some freshly ground black
pepper i'm also going to add a couple
teaspoons of liquid smoke and then about
a cup of boiling water just to give that
stuff a little head start dissolving so
give that a stir set that aside and then
we're going to go over to the blender to
get our nitrates ready so we're going to
put a couple cups of chopped celery in
the blender
celery contains naturally occurring
nitrates and basically that's one of the
things that makes ham taste like ham and
not pork chops I'm also going to throw
in half an onion and a few cloves of
garlic I'm going to add a couple cups of
water just so I can puree this I'm going
to blend that completely smooth and then
we're going to go back over to our brine
I'm going to toss in one bay leaf I'm
going to dump in my celery mixture and
then enough cold water to bring the
level up to two quarts and of course you
want to use a big enough container
that's going to fit the brine and the
pork alright so I'm using a four quart
container which is going to be perfect
so I'm gonna give that a stir and you
want to make sure all that salt and
sugar is dissolved which it should be
but give it a stir to make sure and then
it's on to the pork and what we're going
to use here is for very large the
columns center-cut boneless pork chops
which is fairly ridiculous name it's
just a piece of pork loin I'm going to
suggest you go between ten and twelve
ounces each these are like exactly
eleven so go to a really good butcher
have them cut your pieces exactly the
same size so they cure at the same rate
we're going to go ahead and place our
pork into the brine we're going to cover
that tightly and we're going to brine
this for two days alright so we're going
to pop that in the fridge for 48 hours
in the meantime we can make our brown
sugar mustard glaze don't rush you got
two days and all that's going to be is
some brown sugar some Dijon mustard and
a little bit of cayenne and you're just
going to mix that up and you're going to
end up with this kind of thick paste
which is exactly
what you want and that is ready and then
there's nothing really to do except wait
for your pork to cure and here we are 48
hours later we're going to pull it out
of the brine we're going to dry very
well you don't want to be working with
wet Hamlet's and then we're going to do
some knife work so take your sharpest
knife turn it up on the side that has
the fat and make some very shallow cuts
just barely cutting down to the meat and
you could trim that right off but this
is so lean I hate to lose any of the
existing fat okay so I'm gonna leave it
on there and then we're going to turn it
like this and we're going to take our
knife and we're going to make I don't
know about every half inch 1/4 inch
slice into the meat we're going to turn
it and we're going to go across the
other way to make those sort of diamond
shapes and it's those cuts after this is
cooked and glazed that's going to make
it look like a little ham it's going to
be adorable so once your ham is cut
we're going to go over to the stove and
we're going to brown these in a little
bit of oil on high heat and we don't
have to get these really brown we just
want a little bit of caramelization on
there so go ahead and brown those for a
couple minutes per side and by the way
you do not need to season these that
brine took care of that and once both
sides are browned we're going to make
sure we finish with the cut side up
we're going to take a nice big spoon of
our glaze and before this goes in the
oven we're going to spread that over the
top I'm also going to poke in a couple
whole cloves it's going to give it a
little extra holiday hammy flavor and a
beautiful aroma as they roast and then
those are going to go in a preheated 325
degree oven for about 20-25 minutes
although I don't want you to go by time
it's going to really vary so what you
need to go by is internal temperature we
want to pull these out at 145 you don't
need to cook them any longer than that
as soon as they come out I want you to
take them out of the pan onto a plate so
they don't continue to cook of course
we're gonna let those rest ten minutes
and while we do the final step which is
glazing the top we're going to take our
blowtorch you can also use a hot boiler
of course and we're going to caramelize
the top look at that by the way protip
take out the clothes before you do this
unless you want your kitchen to smell
like clove cigarettes
which reminds me people that smoked
clove cigarettes please stop that thank
you and once those are glazed you're
ready to serve check it out Christmas
Hamlet a meal truly fit for the Prince
of Denmark
or is it Sweden I don't know I'm not
sure I don't even know I'm referencing
Shakespeare I don't even know who wrote
Shakespeare but anyway what I do know
this was incredibly delicious just a
very very subtle hint of smoke just
salty enough not too salty
very lean but didn't seem like it moist
tender I was just thrilled with how
these came out and if you were planning
on having ham for the holidays maybe
consider doing this I think you're going
to be extremely happy with the results
so I really hope you give that a try
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
